title: 'From the coal face to the car park? The intersection of class and gender in women's lives in the North East'
abstractText:
This project is a study of women's lives in the North East,  unpacking the interconnections between class and gender with attention to regional specificity. The title aims to convey the multidimensional nature of this research which explores a 'new' feminised social mobility and the relevance and retention of class.

This project contains a strong comparative dimension, crucial to the overall goal of highlighting women's varied positioning within regional transition/stagnation and the significance of gender and class in mediating identifications with 'past' landscapes and present desires, aspirations and material (im)possibilities. It investigates the emergence of new femininities in a situation of industrial degeneration and regeneration, investigating what has hitherto been under-researched when compared with the attention that has focused on boys' and men's experiences of these social processes. This is achieved by conducting  in-depth interviews with women across class positions and age range (n=97), using three differently classed locations as the basis of recruitment.

Taylor, Y. (2011) Fitting Into Place? Class and Gender Geographies and Temporalities. Ashgate
